DOC.HEAD: Bush Using `Tough Terms' in Negotiations with Vatican About Noriega
Eds: SUBS 2nd graf with 1 graf to include definition of `Mexican standoff'
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration demanded ``in extraordinarily tough terms'' Monday that Vatican authorities turn deposed Panamanian dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega over to U.S. custody, a State Department source said. Negotiations have brought ``a Mexican standoff'' _ a confrontation that neither side can win _ the official said, with church authorities rebuffing the request and trying, thus far unsuccessfully, to find a country to take Noriega from his sanctuary in the Vatican Embassy in Panama City. While the negotiations went on, President Bush summoned National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft to his mountain retreat Christmas Day to discuss diplomatic options for dislodging Noriega to bring him to trial on drug charges in the United States. And speaking in Panama, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said he would like to bring U.S. troops home ``as soon as possible'' but added, ``They will stay as long as they are needed. We don't want to leave too soon before the task is accomplished.'' Roughly 26,000 U.S. troops are in Panama, more than double the 12,000 normally based there. The State Department source, speaking only on condition he not be named, said the U.S. demand for custody of Noriega has been delivered to the Vatican ``in extraordinarily tough terms.'' But he said the Vatican has been contacting a number of Latin American and European countries hoping that one will agree to accept Noriega. The officials didn't mention names but countries that have surfaced as possible refuges include Spain, Cuba and the Dominican Republic. ``He has no place to go yet,'' the official said. ``Nobody wants him.'' The official said most of the discussions have been carried out between the State Department and church officials at the Vatican. Vatican spokesman Joaquin Navarro said in Rome it was too early to say whether he would be handed over to the United States or the new U.S.-backed government in Panama or given passage to another country. Scowcroft was asked to come to Camp David in the Catoctin Mountains of Maryland where the president was spending a holiday weekend with his wife, five children and 11 grandchildren. The White House said Secretary of State James A. Baker III was keeping in touch by telephone from Houston where he spent the holiday. Meanwhile, a Panamanian officer and Noriega loyalist who had been indicted with Noriega on drug-related charges in Florida, was escorted to Miami on Monday by U.S. drug enforcement agents, the Justice Department said. Lt. Col. Luis del Cid, surrendered to U.S. forces in Panama on Saturday. Noriega entered the Vatican Embassy on Sunday after eluding capture by American troops in the four days since their invasion, despite a $1 million bounty offered by the United States. That relieved U.S. forces in Panama from their intensive and frustrating task of locating him, but it also set in motion a diplomatic and legal ballet. ``Now it's up to the lawyers and the diplomats,'' said Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, in Panama for a brief on-site inspection. Sanctuary in embassies usually is granted for people seeking political asylum, not protection from criminal prosecution. ``We want him in the United States to face the indictments,'' said a member of the State Department's Task Force on Panama. ``We are exploring avenues by which this might be done,'' said the official, who insisted on anonymity. Reports from Panama mentioned the possibility that Noriega wants to go to Spain or Cuba. When U.S. officials were negotiating with the Panamanian strongman after his indictment in this country last year, he reportedly expressed a willingness to go into exile in either country, but in the end did not. Miguel Gil, a spokesman for the Spanish government, said no official overtures had been made by Noriega. And Foreign Minister Francisco Fernandez Ordonez said the case was a matter to be decided between the United States and the Vatican. Spain's national news agency, EFE, later reported him as saying, ``Spain is not the ideal country to accept Noriega because of its extradition agreement with the United States, which includes drug trafficking (cases).'' In Vatican City, spokesman Joaquin Navarro said ``the concerned parties'' would examine the case as soon as possible and that Noriega's legal status was still being determined. Navarro was asked in a television interview if a ``simple'' turnover of Noriega to the United States was foreseeable. ``Well, I don't think so,'' said Navarro. ``There isn't an extradition treaty or anything.'' The Pentagon issued new casualty figures in Panama. The death toll of U.S. troops stood at 23, revised downward by one from Sunday because one victim was counted by two different units. There were 303 U.S. wounded, none missing and two dependents killed, Lundquist said. He said Noriega's routed Panamanian Defense Forces suffered 290 dead, 121 wounded, and 3,780 captured or detained.
